items.title: President Trump plans to rename the Defense Department as the Department of War
items.standfirst: The change would return the department to a name that it carried for much of its history, until it became the Department of Defense in the wake of World War II.
items.content: The change would return the department to a name that it carried for much of its history, until it became the Department of Defense in the wake of World War II.(Image credit: Daniel Slim)

items.title: Trump to rename Defence Department as 'Department of War'
items.standfirst: Seeking to accomplish a long-gestating goal, US President Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order on Friday that the Department of Defence be renamed as the Department of War, using the US military branch's original name as a "secondary" title until Congress authorises a formal alteration.
items.content: Seeking to accomplish a long-gestating goal, US President Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order on Friday that the Department of Defence be renamed as the Department of War, using the US military branch's original name as a "secondary" title until Congress authorises a formal alteration.

items.title: What do Americans think of RFK Jr. and vaccines?
items.standfirst: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. testified on Capitol Hill Thursday where he denied limiting access to vaccines. Despite his denial, CBS News polling found Americans do believe Kennedy Jr.'s policies have had an impact on vaccine availability. CBS News executive director of elections and surveys, Anthony Salvanto, has more.
items.content: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. testified on Capitol Hill Thursday where he denied limiting access to vaccines. Despite his denial, CBS News polling found Americans do believe Kennedy Jr.'s policies have had an impact on vaccine availability. CBS News executive director of elections and surveys, Anthony Salvanto, has more.

items.title: RFK Jr. faces heated questions on CDC, vaccines at Senate hearing

items.content: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. defended firing the director of the CDC at a hearing before a Senate committee on Thursday.

items.title: Trump to sign executive order renaming Defense to Department of War
items.standfirst: President Trump will sign an executive order Friday directing the Department of Defense to use the name Department of War as a "secondary title" — restoring a name it last held in the late 1940s.
items.content: President Trump will sign an executive order Friday directing the Department of Defense to use the name Department of War as a "secondary title" — restoring a name it last held in the late 1940s.

items.title: Watch: Key moments from RFK Jr's heated Senate hearing

items.content: The US health secretary faced questions on Covid deaths and vaccines a week after firing the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

ai_summary: Trump intends to rename the Department of Defense to the Department of War.
The change would revert the department to its pre-1947 name.
The order would authorize the Defense Secretary to use the title "Secretary of War".
Trump has renamed other things since returning to the White House.
The change follows Trump's executive order titled "Restoring names that honor American".

clusters.title: French national among 16 people killed in Lisbon funicular train crash
clusters.neutral_headline: Lisbon Funicular Crash Claims Sixteen Lives

items.title: French national among 16 people killed in Lisbon funicular train crash
items.standfirst: A French woman died in the Lisbon funicular train derailment that killed 16 people earlier this week, France's foreign minister confirmed on Friday, as Portuguese authorities investigated what caused the cable car popular with tourists to hurtle down a hill and crash into a building.
items.content: A French woman died in the Lisbon funicular train derailment that killed 16 people earlier this week, France's foreign minister confirmed on Friday, as Portuguese authorities investigated what caused the cable car popular with tourists to hurtle down a hill and crash into a building.

items.title: Boy, 3, pulled from funicular crash that has shocked Portugal
items.standfirst: It is unclear what caused the crash in which 16 people died and more than 20 were injured, including many foreign nationals.
items.content: It is unclear what caused the crash in which 16 people died and more than 20 were injured, including many foreign nationals.

items.title: What we know about Lisbon's deadly funicular crash
items.standfirst: At least 16 people died after a carriage on the city's famous Glória hillside railway derailed.
items.content: At least 16 people died after a carriage on the city's famous Glória hillside railway derailed.

items.content: At least 16 people were killed and 20 more injured, some critically, Portuguese authorities say.

items.content: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.

items.title: Lisbon funicular crash claims 16 lives - all we know as foreign nationals confirmed among fatalities

items.content: Portuguese authorities have declared three days of mourning after Lisbon's iconic Gloria funicular crashed, killing 16 people and injuring 23.

items.title: At least 15 people killed and 18 injured in crash of funicular railway in Lisbon
items.standfirst: At least 15 people were killed and 18 were injured in a crash of a popular funicular railway in Lisbon, Portugal, on Wednesday, according to local authorities.
items.content: At least 15 people were killed and 18 were injured in a crash of a popular funicular railway in Lisbon, Portugal, on Wednesday, according to local authorities.

ai_summary: A funicular train derailment in Lisbon killed at least sixteen people.
A French woman was among the fatalities in the Lisbon funicular crash.
Authorities are investigating the cause of the deadly funicular crash.
The crash injured over twenty people, including many foreign nationals.
Portugal declared three days of mourning after the funicular accident.

clusters.title: Moscow rejects Western security guarantees for Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: Twenty-Six Nations Pledge Postwar Military Backing for Ukraine

items.title: Moscow rejects Western security guarantees for Ukraine
items.standfirst: The Kremlin's refusal comes after 26 dozen countries pledged to deploy troops to Ukraine in the event of a ceasefire.
items.content: The Kremlin's refusal comes after 26 dozen countries pledged to deploy troops to Ukraine in the event of a ceasefire.

items.title: Macron says 26 nations ready to provide postwar military backing to Ukraine
items.standfirst: French president says allies would either deploy ‘reassurance force’ troops to Ukraine, or be present in the area on land, sea or in the airTwenty-six nations have pledged to provide postwar security guarantees to Ukraine, including an international force on land and sea and in the air, Emmanuel Macron said after a summit at which European leaders sought to pin down Donald Trump on the level of support he is willing to give Kyiv.“The day the conflict stops, the security guarantees will be deployed,” the French president told a press conference at the Élysée Palace in Paris, standing alongside Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Continue reading...
items.content: French president says allies would either deploy ‘reassurance force’ troops to Ukraine, or be present in the area on land, sea or in the airTwenty-six nations have pledged to provide postwar security guarantees to Ukraine, including an international force on land and sea and in the air, Emmanuel Macron said after a summit at which European leaders sought to pin down Donald Trump on the level of support he is willing to give Kyiv.“The day the conflict stops, the security guarantees will be deployed,” the French president told a press conference at the Élysée Palace in Paris, standing alongside Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Continue reading...

items.title: Western troops in Ukraine would be ‘legitimate’ target for Russia, Putin warns
items.standfirst: Any Western troops deployed to Ukraine would be a "legitimate" target for Moscow's army, Russian President Vladimir Putin warned on Friday, a day after 26 countries pledged to deploy protective troops on Ukrainian soil if a ceasefire is reached.
items.content: Any Western troops deployed to Ukraine would be a "legitimate" target for Moscow's army, Russian President Vladimir Putin warned on Friday, a day after 26 countries pledged to deploy protective troops on Ukrainian soil if a ceasefire is reached.

items.title: 26 countries agree to deploy troops in Ukraine if ceasefire reached
items.standfirst: 26 European countries formally agreed on Thursday to provide security guarantees for Ukraine, committing to sending troops to Ukraine in the event of a ceasefire with Russia. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky commended the agreement and said those already in favor of the plan "count on" the US to act as a "backstop" within the framework of security guarantees for his country.
items.content: 26 European countries formally agreed on Thursday to provide security guarantees for Ukraine, committing to sending troops to Ukraine in the event of a ceasefire with Russia. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky commended the agreement and said those already in favor of the plan "count on" the US to act as a "backstop" within the framework of security guarantees for his country.

items.title: 'Very difficult for European leaders, policy planners & Zelensky to know what to expect from Trump'
items.standfirst: As Zelensky meets with French President Emmanuel Macron and 30 allied leaders in Paris, FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley welcomes Michael Bociurkiw, author, journalist and nonresident Senior Fellow at the Atlantic Council's Eurasia Center. Bociurkiw provides in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective on Russia's war on Ukraine, the evolution of a veritable high-tech war and the ever-so perilous path to peace.
items.content: As Zelensky meets with French President Emmanuel Macron and 30 allied leaders in Paris, FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley welcomes Michael Bociurkiw, author, journalist and nonresident Senior Fellow at the Atlantic Council's Eurasia Center. Bociurkiw provides in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective on Russia's war on Ukraine, the evolution of a veritable high-tech war and the ever-so perilous path to peace.

items.title: 26 nations pledge post-war security support for Ukraine, Macron says
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that 26 countries have pledged post-war military support to Ukraine after any ceasefire deal with Russia. Macron said the planned deployments aim to ensure security, not provoke conflict. With US backing expected to be finalised soon, Ukraine's President Zelensky called the move a major step forward.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron announced that 26 countries have pledged post-war military support to Ukraine after any ceasefire deal with Russia. Macron said the planned deployments aim to ensure security, not provoke conflict. With US backing expected to be finalised soon, Ukraine's President Zelensky called the move a major step forward.

items.title: Europe’s security impacts the US: EU holding on to hope Trump won’t ‘sell Ukraine down the river’
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has announced the twenty-six countries who have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia. Meanwhile, Macron assures that the United States have been clear on their will to take part in the security guarantees offered to Ukraine. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective Delano D'Souza welcomes John Lough, Associate Fellow for the Russia and Eurasia Program at Chatham House.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has announced the twenty-six countries who have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia. Meanwhile, Macron assures that the United States have been clear on their will to take part in the security guarantees offered to Ukraine. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective Delano D'Souza welcomes John Lough, Associate Fellow for the Russia and Eurasia Program at Chatham House.

items.title: Macron says 26 countries offer to participate in Ukraine post-war security
items.standfirst: Twenty-six countries have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia, French President Emmanuel Macron said Thursday. "We have today 26 countries who have formally committed -- some others have not yet taken a position -- to deploy as a 'reassurance force' troops in Ukraine, or be present on the ground, in the sea, or in the air," Macron told reporters at a joint press conference with Volodymyr Zelensky following a meeting of allies in Paris.
items.content: Twenty-six countries have signed up to contribute to Ukraine's security after any ceasefire or peace deal with Russia, French President Emmanuel Macron said Thursday. "We have today 26 countries who have formally committed -- some others have not yet taken a position -- to deploy as a 'reassurance force' troops in Ukraine, or be present on the ground, in the sea, or in the air," Macron told reporters at a joint press conference with Volodymyr Zelensky following a meeting of allies in Paris.

items.title: Trump says Putin and Zelenskyy are 'not ready' for peace as European powers meet
items.standfirst: France's Macron is hosting Ukraine's Zelenskyy in Paris with hopes he will underwrite "security guarantees" in the event of a ceasefire with Russia.
items.content: France's Macron is hosting Ukraine's Zelenskyy in Paris with hopes he will underwrite "security guarantees" in the event of a ceasefire with Russia.

ai_summary: Twenty-six nations agreed to provide security guarantees for Ukraine.
These nations will send troops in the event of a ceasefire with Russia.
The agreement includes an international force on land, sea, and air.
Russia warned that Western troops in Ukraine would be a target.
Macron said allies would deploy troops or be present in the area.

items.title: Trump hosts US tech leaders at White House dinner – minus Elon Musk
items.standfirst: Tesla CEO’s absence is marked departure from his constant presence at the White House in early days of Trump 2.0As Donald Trump hosted leaders from the biggest US tech companies at a lavish White House state dining room dinner on Thursday night, there was one notable absence. Elon Musk, once inseparable from Trump and a constant, contentious presence in the White House, was not in attendance.The dinner, which included Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg, Microsoft’s Bill Gates, Apple’s Tim Cook and OpenAI’s Sam Altman, was exactly the type of event where Musk would have sat at Trump’s right hand only a few months ago. Instead, the Tesla CEO stated on his social media platform X that he had been invited but could not make it. He said he planned to send a representative and spent the day on X posting a familiar stream of attacks on immigration and trans people. Continue reading...
items.content: Tesla CEO’s absence is marked departure from his constant presence at the White House in early days of Trump 2.0As Donald Trump hosted leaders from the biggest US tech companies at a lavish White House state dining room dinner on Thursday night, there was one notable absence. Elon Musk, once inseparable from Trump and a constant, contentious presence in the White House, was not in attendance.The dinner, which included Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg, Microsoft’s Bill Gates, Apple’s Tim Cook and OpenAI’s Sam Altman, was exactly the type of event where Musk would have sat at Trump’s right hand only a few months ago. Instead, the Tesla CEO stated on his social media platform X that he had been invited but could not make it. He said he planned to send a representative and spent the day on X posting a familiar stream of attacks on immigration and trans people. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump hosts Sam Altman, Mark Zuckerberg, Bill Gates and other tech CEOs at White House
items.standfirst: CEOs from some of the nation's biggest tech companies sat down for a dinner with President Trump on Thursday. Among those present were Tim Cook, Sam Altman, Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg. Bloomberg tech reporter Riley Griffin joins CBS News to discuss.
items.content: CEOs from some of the nation's biggest tech companies sat down for a dinner with President Trump on Thursday. Among those present were Tim Cook, Sam Altman, Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg. Bloomberg tech reporter Riley Griffin joins CBS News to discuss.

items.title: Trump to Host Zuckerberg, Tech CEOs in Redone Rose Garden

items.content: Tech industry leaders including Meta Platforms Inc.’s Mark Zuckerberg, Apple Inc.’s Tim Cook, and Microsoft Corp.’s Satya Nadella are expected to attend an artificial intelligence event hosted by First Lady Melania Trump on Thursday and then join President Donald Trump for an evening reception in the newly renovated Rose Garden.

ai_summary: President Trump hosted tech leaders at a White House dinner.
Tech CEOs praised Trump's leadership at the dinner.
Mark Zuckerberg, Bill Gates, and Tim Cook attended the dinner.
Elon Musk was notably absent from the White House dinner.
Trump pressed leaders on their investments in the United States.

clusters.title: Venezuelan military planes buzzed US ship in ‘highly provocative move’, Pentagon says

items.title: Venezuelan military planes buzzed US ship in ‘highly provocative move’, Pentagon says
items.standfirst: Two Venezuelan military aircraft flew near a US Navy vessel in international waters, the Pentagon disclosed Thursday, in what it called a "highly provocative" escalation. The incident came days after US strikes on a Venezuelan boat in the the Caribbean killed 11 people. President Donald Trump said the Venezuelan vessel belonged to a drug cartel.

clusters.title: Prosecutors launch probe into Argentina couple over Nazi-looted painting

items.title: Prosecutors launch probe into Argentina couple over Nazi-looted painting
items.standfirst: The painting, Portrait of a Lady, had disappeared from the collection of a Jewish art dealer during World War II.
items.content: The painting, Portrait of a Lady, had disappeared from the collection of a Jewish art dealer during World War II.

items.title: Long-lost painting looted by Nazis recovered in Argentina
items.standfirst: A long-lost painting by Italian master Giuseppe Ghislandi, which was looted by the Nazis, has been recovered in Argentina after it was spotted in an online property listing. "Portrait of a Lady" is an 18th century painting which belonged to a Jewish art collector before it was stolen during World War II. The artwork is now with the federal prosecutor's office.
items.content: A long-lost painting by Italian master Giuseppe Ghislandi, which was looted by the Nazis, has been recovered in Argentina after it was spotted in an online property listing. "Portrait of a Lady" is an 18th century painting which belonged to a Jewish art collector before it was stolen during World War II. The artwork is now with the federal prosecutor's office.

items.title: Long-lost painting looted by Nazis recovered after it was spotted in a real estate listing
items.standfirst: It took 80 years to track down and a week of international intrigue, but a long-lost 18th-century painting looted by the Nazis has been recovered after it was spotted in a recent Argentinian real estate listing.
items.content: It took 80 years to track down and a week of international intrigue, but a long-lost 18th-century painting looted by the Nazis has been recovered after it was spotted in a recent Argentinian real estate listing.

The painting is titled "Portrait of a Lady".
The painting was missing for eighty years.
It was spotted in an online property listing.
The painting belonged to a Jewish art collector.

items.title: ‘We’re scared of losing our jobs’: industries in India fear impact of Trump’s 50% tariffs
items.standfirst: Textiles, footwear, jewellery, gems and seafood are sectors most affected in trade with US, India’s biggest marketIndia has long been one of the world’s great garment houses, turning out everything from cheap T-shirts to intricate embroidery. Last year, textile and garment exports to the US alone fetched £21bn, riding a wave of strong consumer demand.Now the trade is in jeopardy. With the stroke of a pen, the US president, Donald Trump, last week slapped a 50% tariff on more than half of India’s £65bn worth of merchandise exports to the country’s largest market. A supply chain once prized for being cheap suddenly became among the priciest. Continue reading...
items.content: Textiles, footwear, jewellery, gems and seafood are sectors most affected in trade with US, India’s biggest marketIndia has long been one of the world’s great garment houses, turning out everything from cheap T-shirts to intricate embroidery. items.standfirst: The presidents of China and Russia were overheard discussing transplants as a way to prolong life.
items.content: The presidents of China and Russia were overheard discussing transplants as a way to prolong life.

items.title: Xi and Putin discuss organ transplants and immortality in hot mic moment
items.standfirst: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin could be heard discussing organ transplants and immortality in an exchange at a military parade.
items.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin could be heard discussing organ transplants and immortality in an exchange at a military parade.

items.title: Hot mic catches Xi and Putin discussing organ transplants and immortality
items.standfirst: The Chinese and Russian leaders have been in power for 13 and 25 years respectively, with neither expressing any intention of stepping down.
items.content: The Chinese and Russian leaders have been in power for 13 and 25 years respectively, with neither expressing any intention of stepping down.

ai_summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed organ transplants.
The leaders were overheard during a military parade in a hot mic moment.
Both leaders have been in power for many years without plans to step down.
The discussion included the topic of immortality, according to reports.
The conversation was captured by a hot mic during the event.

clusters.title: Thursday briefing: China flexes its muscle in the tussle for global dominance
clusters.neutral_headline: China Hosts Military Parade, Xi Speaks on Global Choices

items.title: Thursday briefing: China flexes its muscle in the tussle for global dominance
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: In hosting anti-western leaders at its largest ever military parade, Beijing sent a defiant message that will be heard loud and clear across the worldGood morning. All eyes have been on China this week as the second biggest global economy flexed its muscles.Dozens of world leaders, including from the global south, authoritarian pariah states and the EU, attended China’s largest ever military parade on Wednesday to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the war of resistance against Japanese aggression.UK news | Deputy PM Angela Rayner has admitted she underpaid stamp duty on her £800,000 seaside flat, after coming under intense pressure to be more transparent about her property arrangements.Russia | Vladimir Putin has invited Kim Jong-un to visit Russia during a lengthy meeting in Beijing on the sidelines of China’s biggest military parade, as Kim promised to do “everything I can to assist” Moscow.Police | The Metropolitan police have declined to drop their investigation into the comedy writer Graham Linehan for tweets about trans issues, and said that the law used by officers to detain him needs reviewing.Israel | Israeli drones dropped four grenades near UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon, the agency’s force said on Wednesday, in what it described as “one of the most serious attacks” on its personnel since a November ceasefire.Portugal | A day of national mourning has been declared in Portugal after at least 15 people were killed when Lisbon’s well-known Gloria funicular railway car derailed and crashed on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: In hosting anti-western leaders at its largest ever military parade, Beijing sent a defiant message that will be heard loud and clear across the worldGood morning. All eyes have been on China this week as the second biggest global economy flexed its muscles.Dozens of world leaders, including from the global south, authoritarian pariah states and the EU, attended China’s largest ever military parade on Wednesday to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the war of resistance against Japanese aggression.UK news | Deputy PM Angela Rayner has admitted she underpaid stamp duty on her £800,000 seaside flat, after coming under intense pressure to be more transparent about her property arrangements.Russia | Vladimir Putin has invited Kim Jong-un to visit Russia during a lengthy meeting in Beijing on the sidelines of China’s biggest military parade, as Kim promised to do “everything I can to assist” Moscow.Police | The Metropolitan police have declined to drop their investigation into the comedy writer Graham Linehan for tweets about trans issues, and said that the law used by officers to detain him needs reviewing.Israel | Israeli drones dropped four grenades near UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon, the agency’s force said on Wednesday, in what it described as “one of the most serious attacks” on its personnel since a November ceasefire.Portugal | A day of national mourning has been declared in Portugal after at least 15 people were killed when Lisbon’s well-known Gloria funicular railway car derailed and crashed on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Xi Jinping says world faces ‘peace or war’, as Putin and Kim join him for military parade
items.standfirst: Trump criticises victory day event as China caps off week of diplomatic grandstanding seen as rebuke to the westXi Jinping said the world was facing a choice between peace or war as he held China’s largest-ever military parade, joined by Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un in a show of defiance to the west.Putin and Kim, the authoritarian leaders of Russia and North Korea, were among dozens of world leaders who attended the parade, a massive display of military hardware and personnel, orchestrated to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump criticises victory day event as China caps off week of diplomatic grandstanding seen as rebuke to the westXi Jinping said the world was facing a choice between peace or war as he held China’s largest-ever military parade, joined by Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un in a show of defiance to the west.Putin and Kim, the authoritarian leaders of Russia and North Korea, were among dozens of world leaders who attended the parade, a massive display of military hardware and personnel, orchestrated to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression. Continue reading...

items.title: China parades its military might, and its friends, in a defiant display for the U.S.
items.standfirst: China held a lavish military parade on Wednesday marking the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II, with Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un in attendance.
items.content: China held a lavish military parade on Wednesday marking the 80th anniversary of the end of World War II, with Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un in attendance.

ai_summary: China hosted its largest military parade, attended by global leaders.
Xi Jinping stated the world faces a choice between peace or war.
Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un attended the parade in Beijing.
The parade marked the 80th anniversary of the end of WWII.
Deputy PM Angela Rayner admitted underpaying stamp duty on a flat.

clusters.title: China's Xi believes in destiny - and it's bad news for the West
clusters.neutral_headline: China's Military Strength Display Concerns Western Powers

items.title: China's Xi believes in destiny - and it's bad news for the West
items.standfirst: China put on a show of military strength and diplomatic pulling power in Beijing this week that should worry us all.
items.content: China put on a show of military strength and diplomatic pulling power in Beijing this week that should worry us all.

items.title: What new weapons on show at huge parade say about China's military strength
items.standfirst: Beijing has unveiled a range of military hardware in a show of might to Western powers.
items.content: Beijing has unveiled a range of military hardware in a show of might to Western powers.

ai_summary: China displayed military strength and diplomatic influence in Beijing.
The display included new military hardware, according to reports.
The event has caused concern among Western powers.
The parade was a show of might to Western powers.
China's actions are seen as a cause for concern.
